headline: Stage-specific upregulation during intracellular development with peak expression at 24-48 hours post-infection
one_paragraph_summary:
This Cryptosporidium parvum gene exhibits pronounced stage-specific expression with consistent upregulation during intracellular development phases. Expression patterns show
  • Dramatic increase from oocysts (3.35 TPM) to intracellular stages (103.78 TPM), representing a ~31-fold upregulation
  • Time-dependent expression peaking at 24-48 hours post-infection across multiple experimental systems
  • Biphasic response with maximum expression at 24h and secondary peak at 6h in life cycle studies
  • Preferential expression in natural host environment (calf intestine) compared to cell culture systems
The consistent temporal and stage-specific expression pattern suggests this gene plays a critical role in establishing and maintaining intracellular infection, potentially involved in parasite development, host cell interaction, or metabolic adaptation during the transition from environmental to intracellular stages.

topics.headline: Temporal expression dynamics show peak activity at 24-48 hours post-infection
topics.one_sentence_summary: Multiple time-course experiments consistently demonstrate that this gene reaches maximum expression between 24-48 hours post-infection, with a characteristic biphasic pattern showing early activation at 6 hours and sustained high expression through mid-stage development.

topics.headline: Dramatic stage-specific upregulation during transition from oocysts to intracellular development
topics.one_sentence_summary: The gene shows striking stage-specific regulation with ~31-fold higher expression in intracellular stages compared to oocysts, indicating essential functions during the parasitic phase of the Cryptosporidium parvum life cycle.

topics.headline: Enhanced expression in natural host environment compared to cell culture systems
topics.one_sentence_summary: Expression levels are highest in calf small intestine samples (42-61 TPM) compared to HCT-8 cell culture infections (15-27 TPM), suggesting host environment-dependent regulation of this gene's function.
